tokenModal.description: Please enter your API token to continue using the system.

dashboard.title: Dashboard
dashboard.gettingStartedDesc: Quick guide to using the Headscale Dashboard
dashboard.overviewDesc: The Headscale Dashboard provides a web interface to manage your Headscale network. You can view and manage machines, users, routes, and access control lists.
dashboard.overviewDesc2: Use the sidebar to navigate between different sections of the dashboard.
dashboard.quickStart1Desc: Go to <setup>Setup</setup> to see instructions for connecting machines
dashboard.quickStart2Desc: Visit <preauthKeys>PreAuth Keys</preauthKeys> to generate keys for easy machine connection
dashboard.quickStart3Desc: Use the <machines>Machines</machines> page to view and manage connected devices
dashboard.machinesFeature: View and manage all connected devices
dashboard.aclsFeature: Set up access control rules for your network

setup.title: Connect a Machine
setup.description: Follow these steps to connect a machine to your Headscale network
setup.preAuthKeyAlert: Before connecting a machine, make sure you have generated a pre-auth key from the <preauthKeys>PreAuth Keys</preauthKeys> page.
setup.needPreAuthKeyDesc: Generate a pre-authentication key to connect machines without manual approval

linux.installDesc: Install Tailscale client on your Linux machine
linux.connectDesc: Connect your machine to Headscale using a pre-auth key
linux.verifyDesc: Check if your machine is connected

windows.downloadDesc: Download the Tailscale client for Windows
windows.connectDesc: Connect to Headscale using a pre-auth key
windows.verifyDesc: Check if your machine is connected

macos.installDesc: Install Tailscale using Homebrew or download from website
macos.connectDesc: Connect to Headscale using a pre-auth key
macos.verifyDesc: Check if your machine is connected

machines.title: Machines
machines.guideDesc: Learn how to manage machines in your Headscale network
machines.whatAreMachinesDesc1: Machines are devices (computers, servers, etc.) that are connected to your Headscale network. Each machine has a unique identifier and can communicate with other machines in the network.
machines.whatAreMachinesDesc2: Machines are associated with users and can have tags and routes configured.
machines.viewingDetailsDesc: Click on any machine in the list to view detailed information including:
machines.viewingDetailsList3: Online status and last seen time
machines.renameMachineDesc: Use the rename action to change a machine's display name for easier identification.
machines.expireMachineDesc: Expire a machine to disconnect it from the network. You can set an expiration date or expire immediately.
machines.deleteMachineDesc: Permanently remove a machine from your network. This action cannot be undone.
machines.moveMachineDesc: Transfer a machine from one user to another. Useful for reorganizing your network.
machines.tagsDesc: Assign tags to machines for easier organization and ACL-based access control.
machines.routesDesc: Configure which network routes a machine can advertise and use. Routes allow machines to access subnets and other networks.
machines.tagsRoutesNote: Use the "Manage Tags" and "Manage Routes" actions from the machine dropdown menu.
machines.noMachinesFoundSearch: No machines found matching your search.

users.title: Users
users.guideDesc: Learn how to manage users in your Headscale network
users.whatAreUsersDesc1: Users in Headscale are organizational units that group machines together. Each user can have multiple machines associated with it.
users.whatAreUsersDesc2: Users help organize your network and can be used in ACL policies to control access between different groups of machines.
users.creatingUsersNote: User names must be unique and follow Headscale naming conventions.
users.renameUserDesc: Change a user's name. This updates the user identifier across all associated machines.
users.deleteUserDesc: Remove a user from your network. Note: This does not delete the machines, but they will need to be reassigned to another user.
users.userMachineRelationshipsDesc: Each machine in your network is associated with a user. You can:
users.userMachineRelationshipsList1: View all machines belonging to a user
users.userMachineRelationshipsList3: Use users in ACL policies to control access
users.userMachineRelationshipsNote: To move a machine to a different user, go to the Machines page and use the "Move" action.
users.noUsersFoundSearch: No users found matching your search.

routes.title: Routes
routes.searchPlaceholder: Search routes by prefix, machine, or user...
routes.noRoutesMatching: No routes found matching your search.
routes.guideDesc: Learn how to manage network routes in Headscale
routes.whatAreRoutesDesc1: Routes allow machines in your Headscale network to access subnets and other networks. A route represents a network path that a machine can advertise or use.
routes.whatAreRoutesDesc2: Routes are typically used to connect your Headscale network to local networks, allowing machines to access resources on those networks.
routes.howRoutesWorkDesc1: When a machine advertises a route, it tells other machines in the network that it can provide access to a specific subnet. Other machines can then use that route to reach resources on that subnet.
routes.howRoutesWorkDesc2: Routes must be approved (enabled) before they can be used. This provides security by requiring explicit approval for network access.
routes.enableRouteDesc: Approve a route to allow machines to use it. Enabled routes are active and can be used for network access.
routes.disableRouteDesc: Disable a route to revoke access. The route will no longer be available for use by other machines.
routes.deleteRouteDesc: Permanently remove a route from your network. This action cannot be undone.
routes.bestPracticesList1: Only enable routes from trusted machines
routes.bestPracticesList2: Review routes regularly to ensure they're still needed
routes.bestPracticesList3: Use descriptive route names for easier management
routes.bestPracticesList4: Consider security implications before enabling routes
routes.bestPracticesList5: Disable unused routes to reduce attack surface

preauthKeys.title: PreAuth Keys
preauthKeys.noKeysFound: No preauth keys found for this user.
preauthKeys.guideDesc: Learn how to use pre-authentication keys to connect machines
preauthKeys.whatArePreAuthKeysDesc1: Pre-authentication keys allow machines to connect to your Headscale network without manual approval. They're perfect for automated deployments and easy machine onboarding.
preauthKeys.whatArePreAuthKeysDesc2: When you generate a pre-auth key, you can use it during machine setup to automatically connect the machine to your network.
preauthKeys.generatingKeysDesc: To generate a new pre-auth key:
preauthKeys.generatingKeysStep2: Select the user for the key
preauthKeys.generatingKeysStep3: Choose if the key should be reusable (ephemeral or not)
preauthKeys.generatingKeysNote: Important: Copy the key immediately after creation, as it won't be shown again!
preauthKeys.usingKeysDesc: To connect a machine using a pre-auth key:
preauthKeys.usingKeysStep1: Generate a pre-auth key from this page
preauthKeys.usingKeysStep3: Follow the setup instructions at Setup
preauthKeys.usingKeysStep4: Use the key with the --authkey parameter
preauthKeys.expirationDesc: Keys can have an expiration date. After expiration, the key can no longer be used to connect new machines.
preauthKeys.ephemeralKeysDesc: Ephemeral keys can only be used once. After a machine connects, the key becomes invalid. Non-ephemeral keys can be reused multiple times.
preauthKeys.expiringKeysDesc: You can manually expire a key before its expiration date. This immediately invalidates the key.

apiKeys.title: API Keys
apiKeys.description: Manage API keys for accessing the Headscale API
apiKeys.noKeysFound: No API keys found. Create one to get started.
apiKeys.noKeysMatching: No API keys found matching your search.
apiKeys.guideDesc: Learn how to manage API keys for Headscale API access
apiKeys.whatAreApiKeysDesc1: API keys are authentication tokens that allow you to access the Headscale API programmatically. They're used by this dashboard and can be used by other applications to interact with Headscale.
apiKeys.whatAreApiKeysDesc2: API keys provide secure access to the Headscale API without requiring user credentials.
apiKeys.generatingApiKeysDesc: To generate a new API key:
apiKeys.generatingApiKeysNote: Important: Copy the key immediately after creation, as it won't be shown again! Store it securely.
apiKeys.usingApiKeysDesc: API keys are used for authentication when making requests to the Headscale API:
apiKeys.usingApiKeysList1: Include the key in the Authorization header: Bearer YOUR_KEY
apiKeys.usingApiKeysList2: This dashboard uses API keys automatically when you enter one in the header
apiKeys.usingApiKeysList3: Other applications can use API keys for programmatic access
apiKeys.securityBestPracticesList1: Never share API keys publicly or commit them to version control
apiKeys.securityBestPracticesList2: Use different keys for different applications
apiKeys.securityBestPracticesList3: Set expiration dates for keys when possible
apiKeys.securityBestPracticesList4: Regularly rotate keys and delete unused ones
apiKeys.securityBestPracticesList5: Monitor key usage and revoke compromised keys immediately
apiKeys.securityBestPracticesList6: Use the minimum permissions necessary for each key
apiKeys.importantSaveKey: Important: Save this key now. It will not be shown again!

acls.title: Access Control Lists
acls.guideDesc: Learn how to configure Access Control Lists for your Headscale network
acls.whatAreAclsDesc1: Access Control Lists (ACLs) define which machines and users can communicate with each other in your Headscale network. They provide fine-grained control over network access.
acls.whatAreAclsDesc2: ACLs use a policy file written in JSON format that specifies access rules, groups, and hosts.
acls.aclPolicyStructureDesc: An ACL policy consists of four main sections:
acls.groupsDesc: Define groups of users or machines that can be referenced in ACL rules.
acls.hostsDesc: Define hostnames and IP addresses that can be referenced in ACL rules.
acls.aclsSectionDesc: Define access rules specifying which groups/hosts can access which resources.
acls.testsDesc: Define test cases to validate your ACL configuration.
acls.configuringAclsStep1: Edit the JSON policy in the editor below
acls.configuringAclsStep2: Use the "Format JSON" button to validate and format your policy
acls.configuringAclsStep3: Click "Save Changes" to apply the ACL configuration
acls.configuringAclsStep4: Changes take effect immediately after saving
acls.configuringAclsNote: The editor will show an error if your JSON is invalid. Make sure to fix any errors before saving.
acls.moreExamples: For more examples and documentation, refer to the Headscale ACL documentation.

aclEditor.title: ACL Configuration
aclEditor.description: Edit the Access Control List configuration. Changes will be applied immediately.
aclEditor.policyNotConfigured: Policy file is not configured on the Headscale server. You can create a new policy by editing the JSON below and saving.
